text:
Today's Activity: Reflecting on Front-End Design

Let's review some of the work you have done so far.

  • You created a stakeholder map to identify people affected by a water conservation design solution
  • You created a stakeholder profile to analyze one stakeholder in depth
  • You created a scoping table to generate and organize questions (design questions, natural questions and social questions)
  • You read articles and watched videos to research your natural, social and design questions
  • You generated several ideas for design solutions

All this work is front-end engineering design. Front-end engineering design includes practices like mapping, scoping, research, and idea generation-- work to ensure that a design solution meets stakeholder need, that an engineering design solution makes people's lives better in some way. Front-end work is important because if a designer doesn't understand stakeholder need, they could design a solution that people don't need or don't use.

In this lesson you will reflect on what you have learned about designing water conservation solutions that meet stakeholder need. Let's start with your Learning Journal. What did you learn about engineering design? Review your Learning Journal and write down at 3 things you learned in the chart below. For each thing you learned, provide evidence from your Learning Journal. There is one example in the table to help you get started.

When you finish the table, share what you learned with a partner.

tiles.title: What did I learn about front-end design?

attributes.name: I learned...
values: (Example) I learned that if you want to design something for someone you have to think about their life in detail.

attributes.name: My evidence is...
values: (Example) My evidence is that in my stakeholder profile I wrote down different ways that my school principal uses water. I tried to remember what she does every day to find all the ways she uses water.
